text: Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman's 2024-25 budget reduces the fiscal deficit to 4.9% of GDP without additional borrowing. Non-tax revenue, including public sector and RBI dividends, will rise, lowering the revenue deficit from 2.6% to 1.8% of GDP.

text: India shifts focus from fiscal deficit to debt-GDP ratio, keeping a 4.9% deficit for 2024-25. Somanathan and Sitharaman’s Budget speech targets 2026-27 consolidation with 4.5% next year. text: Shareholders are already paying tax at slab rates on dividend received by them. The Budget proposals have gone a step ahead. Consideration received on buyback of shares will now be treated as dividend income in the hands of the shareholders. As a result, buyback will lose its sheen for investors soon. As the new scheme of taxation of buyback will apply only from Oct 1, companies may initiate buyback schemes at the earliest, to complete the process by Sept 30.

text: Individuals miffed at tax collection at source (TCS) proposals have now been offered a small relief - provided they have salary income. At present, a salaried employee may declare income, such as bank interest and rent, to their employer, who factors this and, accordingly, deducts a higher tax against the monthly salary. The employee then does not have to worry about paying advance tax as adequate tax has already been withheld.

text: Amarjit Kaur, 74, from Nihal Vihar, was fatally struck by Geetika Malik’s speeding car while shopping near pillar 412 on Najafgarh Road in Rajouri Garden. Nearby people were alerted by the noise, and Kaur was taken to a hospital where she was declared dead. Malik fled but was arrested on Tuesday after police used CCTV footage and multiple teams to track her. This incident follows a similar one in Geeta Colony in March, where a 65-year-old woman was killed while sweeping outside. Police are still investigating and scrutinizing CCTV footage for more details.
title: Hit-and-run: 74-year-old woman fatally struck by car in Delhi's Rajouri Garden

text: A 26-year-old youth, Nilesh Rai, lost his life in a tragic electrocution incident in Patel Nagar. Rai, a civil services exam aspirant, was electrocuted when he grabbed an iron gate near a waterlogged area. Despite rescue attempts, Rai's body remained stuck to the gate due to entangled threads. Authorities have registered a case of negligence and obstruction in public way. Investigations are ongoing, with forensic teams examining the scene. The electricity distributor attributed the incident to current leakage from damaged motor wiring.
title: In Delhi to crack UPSC, man electrocuted on waterlogged street

text: The Delhi High Court has transferred the investigation of a 23-year-old man's death during communal riots to the CBI, terming it a 'hate crime'. With perpetrators still unidentified and concerns over police negligence, the court's decision aims to ensure a fair and credible investigation process. The case underscores the importance of upholding human rights and addressing issues of mob vigilantism, even when involving law enforcement officials.

Barbera, initially skeptical of Phillips, acknowledged his evolving talent post-'Joker.' These revelations have heightened anticipation for 'Joker 2,' which promises a distinctive, audacious addition to contemporary cinema.

text: A recent study proposes that time might not be a fundamental aspect of the universe but rather an illusion stemming from quantum entanglement. This new perspective aims to address the inconsistencies between our best theories of the universe, which have hindered the development of a unified "theory of everything." Researchers have suggested that by considering time as a result of quantum entanglement, the mysterious connection between two distant particles, they might solve this long-standing problem. The study, published on May 10 in the journal Physical Review A, explores this idea.

text: On Aug. 24, 2023, more than three decades after the first confirmation of planets beyond our own solar system, scientists announced the discovery of six new exoplanets, stretching that number to 5,502. From zero exoplanet confirmations to over 5,500 in just a few decades, this new milestone marks another major step in the journey to understand the worlds beyond our solar system.The DiscoveryWith the discovery of six new exoplanets, scientists have tipped the scales and surpassed 5,500 exoplanets found (there are now 5,502 known exoplanets, to be exact).Just about 31 years ago, in 1992, the first exoplanets were confirmed when scientists detected twin planets Poltergeist and Phobetor orbiting the pulsar PSR B1257+12. In March 2022, just last year, scientists celebrated passing 5,000 exoplanets discovered.Key Facts Scientists have discovered six new exoplanets — HD 36384 b, TOI-198 b, TOI-2095 b, TOI-2095 c, TOI-4860 b, and MWC 758 c — this has pushed the total number of confirmed exoplanets discovered to 5,502.
title: Exploring Nasa's latest exoplanet marvels: 6 fascinating discoveries unveiled
